010package imagingbook.common.math;
011
012import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.CholeskyDecomposition;
013import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.EigenDecomposition;
014import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.MatrixUtils;
015import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealMatrix;
016import org.apache.commons.math3.stat.correlation.Covariance;
017
018/**
019 * <p>
020 * This class implements the Mahalanobis distance using the Apache Commons Math
021 * library. No statistical bias correction is used. See the Appendix G (Sections
022 * G.2-G.3) of [1] for additional details and examples.
023 * </p>
024 * <p>
025 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
026 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
027 * </p>
028 * 
029 * @author WB
030 */
031public class MahalanobisDistance {
032
033        /** The default minimum diagonal value used to condition the covariance matrix. */
034        public static final double DefaultMinimumDiagonalValue = 1.0E-15;
035        
036        /** Used for Cholesky decomposition. 
037         * See {@link CholeskyDecomposition#DEFAULT_RELATIVE_SYMMETRY_THRESHOLD} (1.0E-15), which seems too small). */
038        public static final double DefaultRelativeSymmetryThreshold = 1.0E-6;
039        
040        /** Used for Cholesky decomposition.
041         * See {@link CholeskyDecomposition#DEFAULT_ABSOLUTE_POSITIVITY_THRESHOLD}. */
042        public static final double DefaultAbsolutePositivityThreshold = CholeskyDecomposition.DEFAULT_ABSOLUTE_POSITIVITY_THRESHOLD;
043        
044        private final double minimumDiagonalValue;
045        private final double relativeSymmetryThreshold;
046        private final double absolutePositivityThreshold;
047
048        private final int m;                                    // feature dimension (length of sample vectors)
049        private final double[] mean;                    // the distribution's mean vector (mu)
050        private final double[][] cov;                   // covariance matrix of size n x n
051        private final double[][] icov;                  // inverse covariance matrix of size n x n
052
053        /**
054         * Create a new instance from an array of m-dimensional samples, e.g.,
055         * samples = {{x1,y1}, {x2,y2},...,{xn,yn}} for a vector of n two-dimensional
056         * samples. Uses {@link #DefaultMinimumDiagonalValue} to condition the 
057         * covariance matrix.
058         * @param samples a sequence of m-dimensional samples, i.e.,
059         *      samples[k][i] represents the i-th component of the k-th sample
060         */
061        public MahalanobisDistance(double[][] samples) {
062                this(samples, DefaultMinimumDiagonalValue, DefaultRelativeSymmetryThreshold, DefaultAbsolutePositivityThreshold);
063        }
064        
065        /**
066         * Create a new instance from an array of m-dimensional samples, e.g.
067         * samples = {{x1,y1}, {x2,y2},...,{xn,yn}} for a vector of n two-dimensional
068         * samples.
069         * @param samples a vector of length n with m-dimensional samples, i.e.,
070         *      samples[k][i] represents the i-th component of the k-th sample
071         * @param minDiagVal the minimum diagonal value used to condition the
072         *      covariance matrix to avoid singularity (see {@link #DefaultMinimumDiagonalValue})
073         * @param relSymThr
074         *              maximum deviation from symmetry (see {@link #DefaultRelativeSymmetryThreshold})
075         * @param absPosThr
076         *              maximum deviation from positivity (see {@link #DefaultAbsolutePositivityThreshold})
077         */
078        public MahalanobisDistance(double[][] samples, double minDiagVal, double relSymThr, double absPosThr) {
079                if (samples.length < 2)
080                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("number of samples must be 2 or more");
081                if (samples[0].length < 1)
082                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("sample dimension must be at least 1");
083
084                this.minimumDiagonalValue = minDiagVal;
085                this.relativeSymmetryThreshold = relSymThr;
086                this.absolutePositivityThreshold = absPosThr;
087                
088                this.cov = makeCovarianceMatrix(samples, minimumDiagonalValue);
089                this.mean = makeMeanVector(samples);
090                this.m = mean.length;
091                RealMatrix S = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(cov);
092                // get the inverse covariance matrix
093                this.icov = MatrixUtils.inverse(S).getData();   // not always symmetric?
094        }
095
096//      /**
097//       * Create a new instance from the m x m covariance matrix and the m-dimensional
098//       * mean vector of a distribution of m-dimensional data. The covariance matrix is 
099//       * assumed to be properly conditioned, i.e., has all-positive diagonal values.
100//       * @param cov the covariance matrix of size m x m
101//       * @param mean the mean vector of length m
102//       */
103//      public MahalanobisDistance(double[][] cov, double[] mean) {
104//              this.cov = cov;
105//              this.mean = mean;
106//              this.M = mean.length;
107//              RealMatrix S = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(cov);
108//              // get the inverse covariance matrix
109//              this.icov = MatrixUtils.inverse(S).getData();   // not always symmetric?
110//      }
111
112        // 
113        /**
114         * Conditions the supplied covariance matrix by enforcing
115         * positive eigenvalues on its main diagonal. 
116         * @param S original covariance matrix
117         * @param minDiagVal the minimum positive value of diagonal elements
118         * @return conditioned covariance matrix
119         */
120        private static RealMatrix conditionCovarianceMatrix(RealMatrix S, double minDiagVal) {
121                EigenDecomposition ed = new EigenDecomposition(S);  // S  ->  V . D . V^T
122                RealMatrix V  = ed.getV();
123                RealMatrix D  = ed.getD();      // diagonal matrix of eigenvalues
124                RealMatrix VT = ed.getVT();
125                for (int i = 0; i < D.getRowDimension(); i++) {
126                        D.setEntry(i, i, Math.max(D.getEntry(i, i), minDiagVal));       // setting eigenvalues to zero is not enough!
127                }
128                return V.multiply(D).multiply(VT);
129        }
130
131        // --------------------------------------------------------------
132
133        private static double[] makeMeanVector(double[][] samples) {
134                int n = samples.length;
135                int m = samples[0].length;
136                double[] mu = new double[m];
137                for (int k = 0; k < n; k++) {
138                        for (int i = 0; i < m; i++) {
139                                mu[i] = mu[i] + samples[k][i];
140                        }
141                }
142                for (int i = 0; i < m; i++) {
143                        mu[i] = mu[i] / n;
144                }
145                return mu;
146        }
147
148        /**
149         * Calculates the covariance matrix for a sequence of m-dimensional samples, e.g.,
150         * samples = {{x1,y1}, {x2,y2},...,{xn,yn}} for n two-dimensional
151         * samples. The covariance matrix is conditioned to avoid negative or zero
152         * values on its main diagonal.
153         * @param samples a sequence of m-dimensional samples, i.e.,
154         *      samples[k][i] represents the i-th component of the k-th sample
155         * @param minDiagVal the minimum positive value of covariance matrix diagonal elements
156         *              (see {@link #DefaultMinimumDiagonalValue})
157         * 
158         * @return the covariance matrix for the supplied samples
159         */
160        public static double[][] makeCovarianceMatrix(double[][] samples, double minDiagVal) {
161                if (samples.length < 2)
162                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("number of samples must be 2 or more");
163                if (samples[0].length < 1)
164                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("sample dimension must be at least 1");
165                RealMatrix S = new Covariance(samples, false).getCovarianceMatrix();    // no bias correction!
166                // condition the covariance matrix to avoid singularity:
167                S = conditionCovarianceMatrix(S, minDiagVal);
168                return S.getData();
169        }
170
171        /**
172         * Returns the sample dimension (M) for this instance.
173         * @return the sample dimension
174         */
175        public int getDimension() {
176                return m;
177        }
178
179        //------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
180
181        /**
182         * Returns the covariance matrix used for distance calculations.
183         * @return the conditioned covariance matrix
184         */
185        public double[][] getCovarianceMatrix() {
186                return cov;
187        }
188
189        /**
190         * Returns the inverse of the conditioned covariance matrix.
191         * @return the inverse of the conditioned covariance matrix
192         */
193        public double[][] getInverseCovarianceMatrix() {
194                return icov;
195        }
196
197        /**
198         * Returns the sample mean vector of dimension m
199         * (see {@link #getDimension()}).
200         * @return the sample mean vector
201         */
202        public double[] getMeanVector() {
203                return mean;
204        }
205
206        //------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
207
208        /**
209         * Returns the 'root' (U) of the inverse covariance matrix S^{-1},
210         * such that S^{-1} = U^T . U
211         * This matrix can be used to pre-transform the original sample
212         * vectors X (by X &#8594; U . X) to a space where distance (in the Mahalanobis
213         * sense) can be measured with the usual Euclidean norm.
214         * The matrix U is invertible in case the reverse transformation is required.
215         * 
216         * @return the m x m matrix for pre-transforming the original (m-dimensional) sample vectors
217         */
218        public double[][] getWhiteningTransformation() {
219                CholeskyDecomposition cd = 
220                                new CholeskyDecomposition(MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(icov),
221                                                relativeSymmetryThreshold, absolutePositivityThreshold);
222                RealMatrix U = cd.getLT();
223                return U.getData();
224        }
225        
226
227        //------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
228
229        /**
230         * Returns the Mahalanobis distance between the given points.
231         * @param a first point
232         * @param b second point
233         * @return the Mahalanobis distance
234         */
235        public double distance(double[] a, double[] b) {
236                return Math.sqrt(distance2(a, b));
237        }
238
239        /**
240         * Returns the squared Mahalanobis distance between the given points a, b:
241         * d^2(a,b) = (a-b)^T . S^{-1} . (a-b)
242         * @param a first point
243         * @param b second point
244         * @return the squared Mahalanobis distance
245         */
246        public double distance2(double[] a, double[] b) {
247                if (a.length != m || b.length != m) {
248                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("vectors a, b must be of length " + m);
249                }       
250                double[] amb = Matrix.subtract(a, b);   // amb = a - b
251                return Matrix.dotProduct(Matrix.multiply(amb, icov), amb);
252                
253        }
254        
255        // original version
256//      public double distance2(double[] X, double[] Y) {
257//              if (X.length != m || Y.length != m) {
258//                      throw new IllegalArgumentException("vectors must be of length " + m);
259//              }
260//              // d^2(X,Y) = (X-Y)^T . S^{-1} . (X-Y)
261//              double[] dXY = new double[m]; // = (X-Y)
262//              for (int k = 0; k < m; k++) {
263//                      dXY[k] = X[k] - Y[k];
264//              }
265//              double[] iSdXY = new double[m]; // = S^{-1} . (X-Y)
266//              for (int k = 0; k < m; k++) {
267//                      for (int i = 0; i < m; i++) {
268//                              iSdXY[k] += icov[i][k] * dXY[i];
269//                      }
270//              }
271//              double d2 = 0;  // final sum
272//              for (int k = 0; k < m; k++) {
273//                      d2 += dXY[k] * iSdXY[k];
274//              }                                               // d = (X-Y)^T . S^{-1} . (X-Y)
275//              return d2;
276//      }
277
278        /**
279         * Calculates the Mahalanobis distance between point x and
280         * the mean of the reference distribution.
281         * @param x an arbitrary m-dimensional vector
282         * @return the Mahalanobis distance between the point x and
283         *                      the mean of the reference distribution
284         */
285        public double distance(double[] x) {
286                return distance(x, mean);
287        }
288
289        /**
290         * Calculates the sqared Mahalanobis distance between point x and
291         * the mean of the reference distribution.
292         * @param x an arbitrary m-dimensional vector
293         * @return the squared Mahalanobis distance between the point x and
294         *                      the mean of the reference distribution
295         */
296        public double distance2(double[] x) {
297                return distance2(x, mean);
298        }
299
300}
